column2: British colonial rule over India ends. A largely Muslim state comprising East and West Pakistan is established, either side of India. The two provinces are separated from each other by more than 1,500 km of Indian territory.;1949
column3: The Awami League is established to campaign for East Pakistan's autonomy from West Pakistan.;1970
column4: The Awami League, under Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, wins an overwhelming election victory in East Pakistan. The government in West Pakistan refuses to recognise the results, leading to rioting. Cyclone hits East Pakistan  up to 500,000 people are killed.;1971
column5: Sheikh Mujib arrested and taken to West Pakistan. In exile, Awami League leaders proclaim the independence of the province of East Pakistan on 26th March. The new country is called Bangladesh. Just under 10 million Bangladeshis flee to India as troops from West Pakistan are defeated with Indian assistance.;1972
column6: Sheikh Mujib returns, becomes prime minister. He begins a programme of nationalising key industries in an attempt to improve living standards, but with little success.;1974
column7: Severe floods devastate much of the grain crop, leading to an estimated 28,000 deaths. A national state of emergency is declared as political unrest grows.;1975
column8: Sheikh Mujib becomes president of Bangladesh. The political situation worsens. He is assassinated in a military coup in August. Martial law is imposed.;1976
column10: General Ziaur Rahman assumes the presidency. Islam is adopted in the constitution.;1979
column11: Martial law is lifted following elections, which Zia's Bangladesh National Party (BNP) wins.;1981
column12: Zia is assassinated during abortive military coup. He is succeeded by Abdus Sattar.;1982
column13: General Ershad assumes power in army coup. He suspends the constitution and political parties.;1983
column14: Limited political activity is permitted. Ershad becomes president.;1986
column15: Parliamentary and presidential elections. Ershad elected to a fiveyear term. He lifts martial law and reinstates the constitution.;1987
column16: State of emergency declared after opposition demonstrations and strikes.;1988
column17: Islam becomes state religion. Floods cover up to threequarters of the country. Tens of millions are made homeless.;1990
column18: Ershad steps down following mass protests.;1991
column19: Ershad convicted and jailed for corruption and illegal possession of weapons. Begum Khaleda Zia, widow of President Zia Rahman, becomes prime minister. Constitution is changed to render the position of president ceremonial. The prime minister now has primary executive power. Cyclonic tidal wave kills up to 138,000.;1996
column20: Two sets of elections eventually see the Awami League win power, with Sheikh Hasina Wajed, the daughter of Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, becoming prime minister.;1997
column21: Ershad is released from prison. The opposition BNP begins campaign of strikes against the government.;1998
column22: Twothirds of the country devastated by the worst floods ever. Fifteen former army officers sentenced to death for involvement in assassination of President Mujib in 1975.;2000
column23: September  Sheikh Hasina criticises military regimes in a UN speech, prompting Pakistani leader General Musharraf to cancel talks with her. Relations strained further by row over leaked Pakistani report on 1971 war of independence.;2000
column24: December  Bangladesh expels Pakistani diplomat for comments on the 1971 war. The diplomat had put the number of dead at 26,000, whereas Bangladesh says nearly three million were killed.;2001
column25: April  Seven killed in bomb blast at a Bengali New Year concert in Dhaka. Sixteen Indian and three Bangladeshi soldiers killed in their worst border clashes.;2001
column26: April  High Court confirms death sentences on 12 exarmy officers for killing Mujib. Only four are in custody.;2001
column27: June  Bomb kills 10 at Sunday mass at a Roman Catholic church in Baniarchar town. Bomb at Awami league office near Dhaka kills 22. Parliament approves bill providing protection for Hasina and her sister Sheikh Rehana, who feared that the killers of their father Mujib were out to get them too.;2001
column28: July  Hasina steps down, hands power to caretaker authority, becoming the first prime minister in the country's history to complete a fiveyear term.;2001
column29: September  At least eight people are killed and hundreds injured as two bombs explode at an election rally in southwestern Bangladesh.;2001
column30: October  Hasina loses at polls to Khaleda Zia's Nationalist Party and its three coalition partners.;2001
column31: November  Law repealed which guaranteed lifelong security to former prime minister Sheikh Hasina and sister Sheikh Rehana.;2002
column32: March  Government introduces law making acid attacks punishable by death amid public anger over escalating violence against women.;2002
column33: May  Government orders tightening of safety standards after up to 500 people die when a river ferry goes down in a storm.;2002
column34: June  President Chowdhury resigns after ruling Bangladesh Nationalist Party (BNP) accuses him of taking an antiparty line.;2002
column35: July  Pakistani President Musharraf visits; expresses regret over excesses carried out by Pakistan during 1971 war of independence.;2002
column36: September  Iajuddin Ahmed sworn in as president.;2002
column37: December  Simultaneous bomb blasts in cinemas in a town north of Dhaka kill 17 and injure hundreds.;2004
column38: Opposition calls 21 general strikes over the course of the year as part of a campaign to oust the government.;2004
column39: May  Parliament amends constitution to reserve 45 seats for female MPs.;2004
column40: July onwards  Worst flooding in six years leaves nearly 800 people dead, millions homeless or stranded, and an estimated 20m in need of food aid. September's floods in Dhaka are said to be the worst in decades.;2004
column41: August  Grenade attack on opposition Awami League rally in Dhaka kills 22 people. Awami League leader Sheikh Hasina survives the attack.;2005
column42: January  Prominent Awami League politician Shah AMS Kibria is killed in a grenade attack at a political rally. The party calls a general strike in protest.;2005
column43: 17 August  Around 350 small bombs go off in towns and cities nationwide. Two people are killed and more than 100 are injured. A banned Islamic group claims responsibility.;2005
column44: November  Spate of bombings, blamed on Islamic militants, hits Chittagong and Gazipur.;2006
column45: February  Opposition Awami League ends yearlong parliamentary boycott.;2006
column46: October  Violent protests over government's choice of a caretaker administration to take over when Premier Zia completes her term at the end of the month. President Ahmed steps in and assumes caretaker role for period leading to elections due in January 2007.;2006
column47: November  A 14party opposition alliance led by the Awami League campaigns for controversial election officials to be removed. Chief election commissioner MA Aziz steps aside.;2006
column48: December  Election date set at 22 January. Awami alliance says it will boycott the polls. Awami leader Sheikh Hasina accuses President Ahmed of favouring her rival. Blockade aimed at derailing parliamentary elections paralyses much of the country.;2007
column49: January  A state of emergency is declared amid violence in the election runup. President Ahmed postpones the poll. Fakhruddin Ahmed heads a caretaker administration.;2007
column50: March  Six Islamist militants convicted of countrywide bomb attacks in 2005 are hanged. They include the leaders of Jagrata Muslim Janata Bangladesh and JamaatulMujahideen.;2007
column51: April  Sheikh Hasina is charged with murder. Begum Khaleda Zia is under virtual house arrest. Several other politicians are held in an anticorruption drive.;2007
column52: August  Government imposes a curfew on Dhaka and five other cities amid violent clashes between police and students demanding an end to emergency rule.;2007
column54: June  Sheikh Hasina is temporarily freed to get medical treatment in the US.;2008
column55: August  Local elections take place, seen as a big step towards restoring democracy. Candidates backed by the Awami League party perform strongly.;2008
column56: November  The authorities say general elections will be held on 18 December. Sheikh Hasina returns to lead her party in the poll.;2008
column57: December  General elections: Awami League captures more than 250 of 300 seats in parliament. Sheikh Hasina is sworn in as prime minister in January.;2009
column58: February  Around 74 people, mainly army officers, are killed in a mutiny in Dhaka by border guards unhappy with pay and conditions. Police arrest some 700 guards. A further 1,000 guards are detained in May.;2009
column59: October  The government bans the local branch of the global Islamist organisation Hizbut Tahrir, saying it poses a threat to peace.;2010
column60: January  Five former army officers are executed for the 1975 murder of founding PM Sheikh Mujibur Rahman.;2011
column61: June  Constitutional change scraps provision for a neutral caretaker government to oversee elections.;2012
column62: January  Army says it has foiled a coup planned by "fanatical officers".;2012
column63: MayJune  Key figures from the main Islamist party JamaateIslami, including leader Motiur Rahman Nizami, are charged with war crimes by a government tribunal investigating alleged collaboration with Pakistan during the 1971 independence struggle. Jaamate Islami supporters clash with police repeatedly in following months in protest at the trial.;2012
column64: October  Muslim rioters attack Buddhist villages and shrines in southeast Bangladesh after an image said to show a burnt Koran was posted on Facebook. The government denounces the attacks as "premeditated and deliberate acts of communal violence against a minority".;2013
column65: January  War crimes tribunal sentences prominent Muslim cleric Abul Kalam Azad to death for crimes against humanity during the 1971 independence war. He was tried in absentia, as he had fled abroad.;2013
column66: April  Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina vetoes Islamist bill to outlaw criticism of Islam.;2013
column67: May  European retailers promise to sign an accord to improve safety conditions in factories after a garment factory building collapsed in April, killing more than 1,100 people. Worker protests close hundreds of factories and extract a government pledge to raise the minimum wage and make it easier to form unions.;2013
column68: July  At least two people are killed as police clash with thousands of protesters after the conviction of Ghulam Azam, leader of the JamaateIslami party, for war crimes committed during the 1971 war of independence.;2013
column69: November  Opposition Bangladesh Nationalist Party and JamaateIslami supporters clash with police in protests at the government's refusal to make way for a caretaker administration to oversee parliamentary elections in January, as is the usual custom.;2013
column70: December  Supreme Court upholds death sentence on Islamist leader Abdul Kader Mullah of the JamaateIslami party, who was convicted in February of crimes against humanity during the 1971 war of independence.
